column4: if I want to install the latest java in Ubuntu, where should I install it to? /usr/java ?
not sure where you're getting it from, but usually it's under /usr/local/lib/java
if you're installing it yourself and not using a repo
should I first un-install java from Synaptic?
basically I need to upgrade to the latest Java ... the Java in the repos is too old
no, usually i keep around older versions of java for compatibility. you sure all your stuff is compatible with the new java?
a lot of java apps call for a specific version, so having the older ones allows apps that require a specific version of java to run
ok... that sounds good... but won't two versions of Java mess the system up?
no...whichever one you set as default (if you don't set one as default, it's the last one installed) will be the default for all
setting one as default is done by modifying the /usr/bin/java link
hmmmm .... I just need the newer Java for one app to run
i suggest you check where your /usr/bin/java points to, in case you have to go back
that was meant for the termnal
mine points to /etc/alternatives/java, which then in points to my current jvm
yah...in turn, check that link under /etc/alternatives..."ls -l /etc/alternatives/java" that'll tell you where the current jvm is pointed to
so just keep that handy, in case you have to go back to the current jvm. you just put back those symbolic links
at the end of all this it seems simpler to just live with out that one app
but this app was working swell in Feisty
you know...the sun java is available from the repo's, you're using the open source one
but I already have then installed... I thnk
do you meant that even though I have it installed already, my system is not using the sun-java packages... and is instead using the os ones?
ok I got into /usr/lib/jvm and these are the folder in there ... cacao  java-1.5.0-gcj-4.2-1.5.0.0  java-6-sun  java-6-sun-1.6.0.03  java-gcj
sounds good, so back up your current link "sudo mv /etc/alternatives/java /etc/alternatives/java~" and then "sudo link /usr/lib/jvm/java-6-sun/jre/bin/java /etc/alternatives/java"
assuming you don't have any java apps open right now...in which case they'll probably break
are those the exact commands I should do?
based upon what you showed under your /usr/lib/jvm yes
ok from terminal "java -version" will tell you which one you're gonna be using, i don't know what pidgin uses, since i don't use pidgin
java: error while loading shared libraries: libjli.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
hmmn. let's switch it back for the moment "sudo rm /etc/alternatives/java" "sudo mv /etc/alternatives/java~ /etc/alternatives/java"
then "update-java-alternatives -l", and which is the most current sun java listed?
ok I did that and there was a bunch of stuff that happened
fantastic...go ahead and try your app now
hey.. your a genius.... its working
why does the Java version tester still say: Oops! You don't have the recommended Java installed.
Your Java version is 1.4.2. Please click the button below to get the recommended Java for your computer.  Â
yes... but I think it was open while we were making changes... would that matter?
it shouldn't...the update-alternatives should've switched over the defaults
update-alternatives --display firefox-javaplugin.so which is the best version listed? i just need that part
ok...good. close firefox, "sudo killall firefox*" and then try the java webpage again
when I did that killall command Firefox remained open
well, try it again...you might have firefox-bin hanging around
ok.. I restarted and its still the same
check your about:config, filter java, and make sure you don't have anything hardcoded to a /usr/lib/jvm/1.4???? path

and then "sudo update-alternatives --auto firefox-javaplugin.so" but i don't think this is the problem, since your firefox plugin already points to the right version (auto just tells it to use the best)
